history.content:
61B can be split into three parts: learning Java, data structures (trees, heaps, etc), and algorithms (graphs, sorting, etc). The things you will need for interviews and internships will be towards the end of 61b.

__________________________________________________

Keep in mind that you can always apply for internships without CS61B and also perform very well in interviews! By no means is any class a prerequisite for working in SWE at any company. What they will be looking for is whether you'll be able to do the work. In order to get interviews, previous related experience helps - previous internships are ideal, but cool personal projects, hackathon projects or similar will do as well. To prep for interviews, I'd recommend grinding out a couple of Leetcode problems. Aim to be comfortable with the Medium difficulty problems, that's about the level of questions you'll be asked. Sometimes, you might even get the exact questions you practiced on Leetcode!

Therefore, I would recommend getting started recruiting asap - since there is nothing CS61B will teach your about interviews that you cannot learn on your own and companies usually have rolling interviews, so recruiting later will mean you'll compete for fewer spots. Also, consider that you can put 61B on your resume at the start of the semester and just apply - once you'll be interviewing, it'll be October or November and you'll know most of the class anyway.

Regarding big companies vs startups/small companies, there's three considerations. FAANG and big unicorns will give you a name-brand on your resume that will allow you to get your foot in the door pretty much anywhere as a SWE. While you won't get that at a startup, big companies are also pretty competitive for internships, which is not necessarily the case at startups. Moreover, it's much easier to network your way into smaller companies. Finally, startups and small companies will be much more hands-on. As an example, during my current internship at a Series B startup, I'm writing production code every day that has serious impact on our business. By contrast, Google, for example, has more than 40,000 engineers, so you'll be much less likely to have significant impact.

61B can be split into three parts: learning Java, data structures (trees, heaps, etc), and algorithms (graphs, sorting, etc). The things you will need for interviews and internships will be towards the end of 61b.

children.subject: I don't think it's obnoxious. Keep in mind though that there's more than 1,000 students in any single semester of 61B alone, many of whom will likely apply to the same or similar companies as you. Now imagine being a recruiter and seeing the 50th resume with BearMaps on it - while BearMaps is fantastic and a really cool project, it will be hard to impress a recruiter with it when many other students are trying to do the same.
Do you include class projects on your resume? Is it obnoxious to do that?

history.content: I'm an incoming sophomore who will be taking CS61B in the fall. I've heard that you can start interning once you take CS61B and that recruiting for CS mostly happens in the fall. Since I'll be taking CS61B during recruiting season, I was wondering when exactly I should be applying for internships. Would it be better to wait until later in the fall (when I have more technical knowledge) to apply? Also, should I be aiming for big companies or just focusing on smaller/medium-sized companies? Any advice would be appreciated, thanks so much!!
history.subject: Recruiting while taking CS61B
